content.question:
A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.

You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

<math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table, with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in hours,” and the heading for row 2 is “S prime of t, in centimeters per hour.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. S prime of t is 2.3. Column 2. t is 3. S prime of t is 2.1. Column 3. t is 8. S prime of t is 1.9. Column 4. t is 12. S prime of t is 1.7. Column 5. t is 14. S prime of t is 1.6."><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" frame="solid" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(hours)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>12</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>14</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(centimeters per hour)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>2.3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1.9</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1.7</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1.6</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></math>

The depth of snow in a field is given by the twice-differentiable function <math alttext="S"><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 14"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="S of t "><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in centimeters and time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in hours. Values of <math alttext="S prime of t "><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the derivative of <math alttext="S"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, at selected values of time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. It is known that the graph of <math alttext="S"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is concave down for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 14"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a)   Use the data in the table to approximate <math alttext="S double prime of 10"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer. Using correct units, explain the meaning of <math alttext="S double prime of 10"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math> in the context of the problem.

frqParts.text:
A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.

You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

<math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table, with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in hours,” and the heading for row 2 is “S prime of t, in centimeters per hour.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. S prime of t is 2.3. Column 2. t is 3. S prime of t is 2.1. Column 3. t is 8. S prime of t is 1.9. Column 4. t is 12. S prime of t is 1.7. Column 5. t is 14. S prime of t is 1.6."><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" frame="solid" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(hours)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>12</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>14</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(centimeters per hour)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>2.3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1.9</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1.7</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1.6</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></math>

The depth of snow in a field is given by the twice-differentiable function <math alttext="S"><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 14"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="S of t "><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in centimeters and time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in hours. Values of <math alttext="S prime of t "><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the derivative of <math alttext="S"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, at selected values of time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. It is known that the graph of <math alttext="S"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is concave down for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 14"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a)   Use the data in the table to approximate <math alttext="S double prime of 10"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer. Using correct units, explain the meaning of <math alttext="S double prime of 10"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math> in the context of the problem.

(b)   Is there a time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 14"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, at which the depth of snow is changing at a rate of 2 centimeters per hour? Justify your answer.

(c)   At time <math alttext="t equals 8"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the depth of snow is 45 centimeters. Use the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="S"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="t equals 8"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to approximate the depth of snow at time <math alttext="t equals 10"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is the approximation an underestimate or an overestimate of the actual depth of snow at time <math alttext="t equals 10"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

(d)   The depth of snow, in centimeters, is also modeled by the twice-differentiable function <math alttext="D"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 14"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="D of t, equals 120 minus, 92 times e raised to the negative of the fraction t over 40, power"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>120</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>92</mn><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in hours. Use the model to find <math alttext="D prime of 10"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Using correct units, explain the meaning of <math alttext="D prime of 10"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.

topic.text: 1.16: Working with the Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT)

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
